Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. is in her office picking up and putting down various pieces of paper and files, while speaking on the phone with Josh.

Dialogues.Line: The Theory of Everything? JOSH (VO) Yes.
Is it comprehensive? JOSH (VO)
C.J. sits down at her desk rummaging through her files.
That was a joke there, pal-o-mine. JOSH (VO) I want you to lead with this.
Carol, I'm missing the OMB stats. Carol is popping in and out of C.J.'s office handing her different files.
They're coming. JOSH (VO) C.J. I want you to lead with this.
I'm not gonna lead with it. CUT TO INT. JOSH'S HOSPITAL ROOM - CONTINUOUS Josh is lying in a bed.
Yes, you are. C.J. (VO) Okay.
So, you got it?
Sure.
I mean, you got what you're suppose to say. C.J. (VO) Carol, also the EPA?
Committee won't be out 'til 3:00. JOSH (VO) C.J. say it for me.
He's making me crazy. JOSH (VO) You know I heard that. C.J. (VO) Yeah, I understand how a speakerphone works.
Say it for me.
Joshua, I really have to get to the briefing room. She starts to put on her jacket.
Say it please.
Psychics at Cal Tech and the FERMI National Accelerator Lab are close to announcing what...
Physicists! Theoretical physicists at Cal Tech...
Not psychics? JOSH (VO) No.
I should jot that down.
Please.
I tell you if it was psychics I'd lead with it. C.J. gets up to leave. JOSH (VO)
Talk to you later mi amor. She heads out the door. JOSH (VO) I don't think you understand how important this is... He continues to ramble but there's no one in C.J.'s office.
The OMB Stats. She hands C.J. some papers.
Thank you. You can set 'em down and let JOSH rant a little before you hang up the phone.
Sure. C.J. walks through JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA and runs into Toby and they start pedeconferencing down the hall.
Yes, ma'am.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics is going to report that the CPI jump 0.7%...
Okay...
...is the biggest one month increase since the Bureau began tracking prices in '52.
All right, let me say this, the market basket used to calculate the CPI is antiquated.
Say outdated.
And doesn't include some regular house hold items...
Yes.
...like computers...
The prices are always dropping...
Yes.

...and doesn't reflect significant technical improvements like airbags in automobiles, which increase the price of the car very slightly, but provide a much greater value to the consumer. You got all that?
Let's find out. Toby walks off in another direction and Leo meets up with C.J.
Leopold.
Mention the HUD secretary is announcing changes in the underwriting criteria for the Federal Housing Administration.
Well, the network's gonna want to break in with special coverage for that. Leo isn't amused.
The adjustments are in FHA related lending.
Seriously, they're going to need time to put together a logo and theme music.
You know the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported...
Reported the CPI jumped by 0.7%.
Thank you. They both enter THE COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE and Leo leaves, only to be replaced by Sam. Sam catches up as they head for the Press Room.
Oh, Holy Interruptus, Batman!
Grant Samuels died.
Really?
Yes.
He's really dead this time?
Yeah.
Cause last time you told me he was dead and he wasn't.
He's dead this time.
Somebody poked him a little to see...
He died, C.J.!
Well, okay, then I shouldn't have made a joke.
I'm almost certain he's dead.
Sam!
I was making a joke, too! What, you work alone?
Give me some...
He's survived by his wife, Eileen, his son, Robert, his two daughters, Priscilla and Patty, and eight grandchildren.
I'm not going to learn their names.
Uh...that's fine.
Eileen, Robert, Priscilla, Patty, and eight grandchildren. And I'm assuming it was complications due to... She gives Sam a knowing look.
Uh... yeah.
You know anything about Theoretical Physics?
Ah... The Grand Unified Theory.
You know anything about it?
No.
Okay. Sam takes off. C.J. continues toward THE PRESS ROOM. CAROL (OS) Folks, please take your seats. The briefing will start now. C.J. hears this, rushes in and takes the podium.

Good morning everybody. I have to start with a sad announcement. Congressman Grant Samuels finally succumbed to pneumonia last night. His wife, Eileen, his son, Robert, his daughters, Priscilla and Patty, and his eight grandchildren are all in the President's thoughts today. I also want to talk this morning about the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the Federal Housing Administration. The camera moves from C.J. to a set of monitors against the wall and it switches to a TV set in JOSH'S HOSPITAL ROOM, where Josh is lying in bed watching C.J.'s briefing.

And as a special treat for our friend, Josh Lyman, who's recovering very nicely at G.W. The President's science advisors is telling us that psychics at Cal Tech and the Fermi National Accelerator Lab..... Josh begins banging the back of his head against the headboard. C.J. (OS) You know what? I'm pretty sure that was supposed to be physicists.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: 12 WEEKS BEFORE ELECTION DAY
Can you believe it?
And all we had to do was get shot at.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Everyone is seated a conference table.

Dialogues.Line: Those numbers are soft.
(sarcastically) Do you think?
You don't?
A week ago the job approval's at 51. We get shot at and it's at 81. Yeah, I think the numbers are soft.
Still... 81%. Leo and Bartlet enter the room. Everyone stands up.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Good morning, everybody. Anybody know what the word 'acalculia' means?
It's the inability to form arithmetic functions. I'm sorry, Mr. President. You wanted to answer your own question, didn't you?
Yeah, but I'll get over it. [starts to sit down]
Good for you, sir. That's very mature.
Shut up.
You're not over it yet, are ya? Everyone sits down.
No.
Okay.
Did we really poll at 81%?
Those aren't internals. It's CNN, USA Today.
It's soft.
(mock surprise) No!
When asked "whose approach on important national problems do you think is generally best, President Bartlet or the Republican leaders of Congress?" Bartlet gets 61%.
Well 19% of the country has clearly made up their minds about me; 20% just feel sorry for me. This is what you want if you're the leader of the free world. Give us an over view.
Mr. President, we got a honest to god shot at taking back the House.
Taking back the house and possibly picking up two seats net in the Senate.
As well as two governorships and maybe a half dozen state Houses.
Where should we be looking?
Indiana 6th, California 4th and 14th...
Michigan 12...
Michigan 12, Texas 12...
Florida 4, 5, and 9...
They're not going to elect a democrat in the Florida 9th.
I'm sorry Florida 8th.
They're not going to elect a democrat there, either. But let's put some time into it. What else?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Charlie is on the phone and Margaret is hanging around Mrs. Landingham's desk. Charlie is trying to ignore her.

Dialogues.Line: (into phone) I can hold or you can call me back.
An inability to form arithmetic functions.
(into phone) Sure.
Apparently, there's a specialized circuit in the brain for numbers. You know where it is?
(into phone) I'm sorry?
It's in the left parietal lobe.
(into phone) Thank you.
Hey, Zoey.
[enters] Hey, Margaret. Where's Mrs. Landingham?
At a funeral. The President's in the Roosevelt room.
I wasn't here to see my father. I was here to see him. (indicates Charlie)
Do you know what 'acalculia' means?
Yes, because I got it at breakfast.
(into phone) Thank you. (hangs up) Hey.
Hi.
Charlie, Mrs. Landingham asked me to ask you to call technical support and have them look at her computer.
Yeah.
You're supposed to ask for a man named Andrew Mackintosh. He's the only one she trusts.
Mackintosh?
Like the apple.
Sure.
Thank you. Zoey and Charlie leave to the HALLWAY.
I called you at home last night.
I didn't get home 'til late.
Where were you?
I was here.
Called here, too.
I'm not lying to you, Zoey.
I don't think you were lying to me, Charlie. I just think you were either at home or here, you didn't return my call.
I was here, I didn't get the message. I was home, I got the message. I didn't return your call 'cause it was late.
I don't mind being woken up.
Well, now I know that.
Now you know that.
(to someone in the hall) Excuse me.
We have been dating for nine months.
I've gotta go in there. Charlie enters THE ROOSEVELT ROOM.
Cumberland, Monroe, possibly Stanwick.
Since you brought up Cumberland and Monroe, can I say a word about the shooting? (beat) It's been a week and the honeymoon's about to be over.
She's right.
We want to be sure it doesn't look like we're taking advantage of the situation.
Why not?
Why not, what?
The entire country was the victim of domestic terrorism. Why not use the soft numbers before they disappear and go after the guns and go after the hate groups?
It doesn't look good.
Looks good to me.
Well, you work for the White House, Toby. I think we were counting on your support, either way.
Mr. President...
C.J., if you get questions about the midterms, say "we haven't thought that far ahead due to recent events."
Oh, and when they ask about the linkage between the approval numbers and the shooting, "the President's deeply gratified by the publics' support but eager to focus on the issues."
Which will be....
I'll let you know. Thank you very much, everyone.
Thank you, Mr. President. Everybody rises as Bartlet stands up.
Mr. President. Charlie hands a note to Bartlet as everyone clears the room.
(reads the note) It's fine. Tell them around 3 o'clock.
Yes, sir.
Was Zoey out there?
Yes, sir.
Is she still here?
I don't know, sir.
Okay. [starts to gather his files] Leo. Leo and Bartlet walk out of the room to the HALLWAY.
Yes, sir.
Did you know Elliot Roush is running to for the school board in Manchester?
I didn't sir, but then, I don't know who Elliot Roush is...
Elliot Roush.
Yes.
My Elliot Roush.
I'm sorry sir, but I'm still not...
I beat him in my first Congressional campaign.
I can't believe I didn't commit that piece of arcane information to memory.
I want some polling numbers on that race.
I don't want you focusing your attention on the school board race in New Hampshire.
Yeah, 'cause looking at two numbers on a piece of paper really takes the life out of me.
I know where this is going...
Get me the numbers. Let me tell you something...
No.
...I'm ready to go out there.
No.
I don't need to wait another week.

Sir, let's play a game of "Who do you think I'm going to agree with?" Fourteen doctors say you should wait another week before you assume a campaign schedule. Who do you think I'm going to agree with?
Get away from me.
Yes, sir. Leo leaves. Bartlet enters the Oval Office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Sam.
Is he here?
Want me to bring him back?
Ah... I'll go get him myself.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE LOBBY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam walks out to the White House lobby and sees a familiar person: TOM JORDAN.

Dialogues.Line: Tom.
Sam, hello.
I hope you weren't waiting too long. They shake hands.
No. I mean, I don't mind. Sam, this is my wife, Sarah.
Hi.
It's nice to meet you. You got married.
Two years, with a baby on the way.
(to Sarah) Is it his? They all chuckle.
Yeah.
Okay, follow me. They all start walking.
Tom and I had a contracts professor at Duke who couldn't stand me.
Those may be your thoughts, Mr. Seaborn, but that's not the law.
If he knew how many times I wanted to tell him to take the law and shove it up his... Hey, have you guys been to the White House?
No.
We were looking forward to a tour.

Ah...Well, that's my office over there. (points to his area) And the President works in that round room over there. (points toward the Oval Office) And nobody else really matters. Come on in. They go inside THE MURAL ROOM.
This is the Mural Room.
Hmm...can you tell us anything about it?
It's called the Mural room. Have a seat. Do you know why I wanted to talk to you? Tom and Sarah sit down, but Sam stays standing.
I really don't.
'Cause the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee asked me to. (beat) Grant Samuels died a few days ago.
Yeah, we saw it on the news.
He wasn't going to be running again anyways, 'cause he was pretty sick and the man who was going to be running in his place...
Seymour Worthen.
Right, isn't going to...
Sy Worthen isn't running?

Tom, you are a phenomenally attractive Democratic candidate for that district. There are 162 games in major league baseball season and the players have a saying "Every team's going to win 54 games, every team's going to lose 54, it's what you do with the other 54 games that counts." In your district, you got democrats, you got republicans, and the other 54 games are women. Specifically young mothers, among who the number one issue is crime. You are a graduate of Oberlin and Duke Law School. You passed up many lucrative opportunities to work in the D.A's office. You are a prosecutor with an exceptional conviction record and certainly nobody can hang "soft on crime" around your neck. You're active in local politics. You're personable. You are articulate and energetic. You are married and you're having a baby.
I thought you didn't know that.
I'm sorry?
When you were out in the lobby, it seemed as if you didn't know that Tom was married and that there was a baby on the way. And now it sounded like you already had that information.
Sarah, there's very little information about your husband that I don't have. And tell your mom happy birthday for me. Sarah blinks in dismay.
Sam.

Tom, you'll have the full weight of the Democratic National Committee, the Congressional Campaign Committee, the Minority leader, whom we hope to make the majority leader, and the President of the United States. What do you say? You want to run for Congress?
There's a lot to consider, Sam. How much time do I have to think about it?
Five minutes. I'll be outside. [leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. and Toby are walking down a hallway.

Dialogues.Line: You're pissed at me?
I'm saying, I could've used your support in there.
You get my support the same way I get yours. When I agree with what you're saying or when I don't care about what you're saying. This time I disagree.
You don't think we should use the moment to get aggressive about guns and hate groups?
I think we were victims of a violent crime and it's unseemly to use this moment at all.
We didn't get the country drunk, C.J. We're not taking advantage of anybody, and even if we were, who cares?
Every Republican spending the next 12 weeks trying to keep control of the House.
Toby! If you and the FBI want to go after hate groups, I'm not the one you have to convince. Go bag the President. They go inside TOBY'S OFFICE. C.J. starts to leave, but turns back.
I will.
I've gotten a lot of calls about pieces people want to do on how staffers are handling the shooting and the aftermath.
Psychologically?
Yeah. I don't think it's a good idea. Do you?
We're not the story.
That's what I'm saying.
Leave me alone. C.J. leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: CONTINUOUS Toby walks in.
(to himself) I got it. I got it. I got it. (beat) I got it. Bonnie, Ginger, I got it.
Excellent!
Way to go!
Sam! BONNIE (OS) Do you know what?
No. Toby enters his office and sets down some files and comes out of his office looking for Sam. Bonnie hands him a note, which he crumples without reading it.
Sam. He looks in Sam's office as Sam walks behind him.
Sam?
I'm right here.
[turns] Oh, I thought you were in there.
I wasn't.
I got it.
Got what?
How to avoid the appearance that we're randomly and generically going after extremist groups in violation of their civil liberties.
We can avoid that appearance by not doing it.
Yes, or with this. The shooting was the action of not one, but at least three card carrying members of West Virginia White Pride. They leave the communications office and down a yellow HALLWAY.
They have cards?
What?
They actually have membership cards?
What the hell? No, Sam, it was an expression.
Okay.
The key phrase is "at least", at least three members. There might be more. We don't know.
So, therefore, FBI has grounds to investigate...
Yes, to investigate or curtail the activities of all extremist organizations....
...under a cover of investigating this one particular crime.
How do we know that whatever young Nazis of Delaware weren't co-conspirators?
It's not an uncommon way to get around the Bill of Rights, Toby. I'm surprised it took you three weeks to come up with it.
Possibly, because, I had no help from anyone else who works in this building.
Toby.
I'm taking it to Leo.
Knock yourself out. (walks off) Toby goes into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
Donna. He follows her as she weaves in and out of the bullpen.
Yes?
You going to see Josh?
I'm taking him his lunch.
Can I come?
No.
Listen...
No.
Donna.
You know the rules.
The rules are dumb.
The rules are not dumb.
Donna, seriously.
I'm perfectly serious, Toby. He's recovering from an attempted murder. He's supposed to be resting and I don't want people going over there getting him fuhtushed.
Fartoost. Don't bring the Yiddish unless you know what you're doing.
You know what word should be Yiddish, but isn't?
Donna
Spatula.
Thank you.
Also, far-fetched.
I need to talk to him about... They go inside JOSH'S OFFICE.
The Hate Crimes and how best to bring it to the President. He's got the papers you wrote. He's got the materials you sent him. You've talked to him on the phone 93 times a day.
And I'd like to go to his apartment and talk to him.
No.
Donna.
Maybe if you hadn't said the rules were dumb. Donna walks out and leaves a dejected Toby in the office.
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Zoey knocks on Leo's door frame.

Dialogues.Line: Hey, Leo.
Hey, kid.
I was looking for my father.
He's making campaign calls.
He's not in the Office.
He's making them from the residence.
Why?
You're father has a very strict interpretation of something called the Pendleton Act, which prohibits campaign donations to be solicited on government property.
It's a little impractical for the President to step across the street to use the pay phone, isn't it?
Exactly.
Isn't the Residence government property, too?
Yes.
Then why....?
Because your father is a demented, demented man. I'm going over there. They start to leave Leo's office.
Leo, these last few days, do you feel like Charlie's been....
No.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: A steward is bringing breakfast for Bartlet, who is sitting on the bed with a phone to his ear. C.J. is standing at the end of the bed.

Dialogues.Line: Sir...
Yes, sir.
The guy is polling at 46%.
I didn't think they had polling data on people running for seats on the Board of Education.
They didn't. I had to have our guys do it.
Sir, do you think you're becoming obsessed with this race?
He's polling at 46%. He's not a joke. He's polling inside the margin.
In a race for the Board of Education, in a school district that has 43 kids.

It has 1100 kids, and you don't take these people seriously 'cause they don't get anywhere nationally, but they don't have to. All they have to do is, bit by little bit, get themselves on the Boards of Education and city councils. 'Cause that's where all the governing that really matters to anybody really happens.
We do a little governing here, Mr. President.
I'm on hold with a guy whose name I've got on an index card. How much governing do you think is going on around here today? And can you believe I'm on hold?
You're not, sir. You finished the call.
I did?
Yes, sir.
How'd it go?
Very well. Leo knocks at the door. He enters with Zoey.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Elliot Roush is now polling at 46%.
How do you know?
I had our people...
You had our people check.
[gets up off the bed] I have 3 daughters who grew up in that school district.
Leave Elliot Roush alone. You beat him already.
And he has come back. Like crab grass pulled from the lawn. Not by the root, but by the other thing.
I stopped by to see how the calls are going.
They're going fine.
Then I'll leave. Bartlet sits down at the settee to eat his breakfast.
Can't tell you how much I'm going to miss you. (to Zoey) You wanted to talk to me?
Not if you're in this mood. C.J. motions for Leo to wait.

(big sigh) This is real and a man, who makes the Spanish Inquisition look like a Barbara Walters Special, is now polling at 46% in your school district, for which I have personally baked things to raise money. (to C.J.) You can go, too.
You baked things? She's a bit amused by this information.
(sternly) You can go.
(more seriously) Thank you, Mr. President. C.J. and Leo leave.
What do you want?
Dad, can I speak to you about Charlie? We follow C.J. and Leo just OUTSIDE THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM.
The calls are going well.
Good.
Listen, Leo, we're still asked to participate in aftermath stories.
Psychological effects?
Yeah and I was wondering....
Don't do it.
No, I know that. But I was wondering...
You're wondering what? C.J.'s beeper vibrates and she checks it.
This isn't going to be good.
You were wondering what?
Don't worry about it.
Okay. (leaves) C.J. picks up a nearby phone and starts dialing.
(into phone) Hey, it's C.J. Cregg.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Step 3: Public disclosure of membership and contributor rolls for all organizations on the Attorney General's list of hate groups. This allows for the American public to know who their people are and where their funding is coming from.
Yes, and to do it in blatant violation of their right to free association.
Sam.
You know, laws like this were passed in the south during the Civil Rights movement to root out members of such terrorist organizations as the NAACP.
I knew you were going to say that.
Yes, you did. By the way, the Supreme Court struck down those laws as unconstitutional.
That was an ultra-activist Warren Court that struck down those laws and I think they'd see it differently, today.
Toby, you're an.... you're an activist!
And I was shot at and so I am acting, right now!
[walks up] Sam.
He wants everyone to have to register affiliation with the FBI.
Any problems with the first Amendment?
I'll get around them. [takes off]
I need to talk to you.
What's up?
There's a problem with your friend.
Which friend?
Tom Jordan, the guy you got running.
What's the problem?
His prosecutorial record.
His prosecutorial record is great.
Not during jury selection. They walk inside THE MURAL ROOM.
Preemptive challenges?
Your friend likes white jurists for his black defendants.
He's a prosecutor, C.J.
Not anymore. Now he's a politician and this needs a save. So, get into it, would you?
Yeah. C.J. leaves the Mural room and Sam stands alone looking around the room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT
CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is at his desk stuffing papers into his briefcase getting ready to leave. Charlie is giving him last minute details.

Dialogues.Line: Do we know how Tokyo opened?
I thought it was up 3/8th against the Yen, but let me check with somebody.
Is that it for me?
No, sir. You've got 4 to 5 phone calls still to make.
Wyman?
Yes, sir.
Frank Gates and McNamara?
Yes, sir.
Those are campaign calls.
Mr. President, why don't you stay in your office and make the damn... Charlie cuts off and realizes that he's gone too far. Bartlet takes off his glasses and looks pointedly at Charlie.

Because I choose not to, Charlie. Because, however an empty gesture it may seem, I would like to take some executive notice of the notion that it's probably not a good idea for the most powerful and influential person in the world to be calling up the people whose laws he signs and asking them for money! (beat) I'm going to do it, but not behind this desk and not in this room. What else?

(hesitantly) I was asked to tell you that an event was added to Tuesday the 7th. A reception for Talk Radio Host. I guess they're called Talk Radio. It's 3 weeks away. You don't need to commit right now.
Yeah. (takes the phone messages) I'll make these calls from the Residence. Tell C.J. I want to see her in an hour.
Yes, sir. Bartlet leaves his office as Charlie thinks about what just happened.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Charlie is walking down the hall by the Roosevelt Room. He sees something in the room that catches his eye and enters.

Dialogues.Line: Hello. Are you a cabinet member? At the end of the conference table is a little boy sitting in one of the chairs. The little boy shakes his head.
Can you tell me your name?
Jeffrey.
Jeffrey what?
Jeffrey Mackintosh.
Like the apple.
Yeah.
You here with your dad? On cue, ANDREW MACKINTOSH enters the room.
Excuse me. I'm sorry. Jeffrey, when I tell you to sit and stay put, do you know what I need you to do? That. I need you to do that. Not some variation on that, but that.
Sorry.
Sorry. Okay, see now I gotta make you rewire the house. (to Charlie) I'm Andrew Mackintosh. I'm from Technical Support. We're installing new software.
Yeah, I thought that was a few weeks ago.
It was, but there was some bugs.
Okay.
I hope nobody minds. They said it was okay to bring my son. My wife works some nights.
Sure.
(to Jeffrey) Let's go big man. Andrew pats Jeffrey and hustles him out of the room.
Take it easy, Jeffrey.
Take it easy. Charlie walks out of the Roosevelt room and passes Sam in the HALLWAY.
Hey, man.
Hey. Sam walks towards LEO'S OFFICE.
Leo. (taps lightly on Leo's door frame)
Oh Sam, come in. Close the door.
What's going on?
Josh is on the speaker. JOSH (VO) Hey, Sam.
What's going on?
A guy who went to college with Tom Jordan says he belonged to an all white fraternity. The local papers are gonna carry it tomorrow.
Yeah. I checked that out weeks ago. It wasn't an exclusive fraternity, they just didn't happen to have any black pledges.
Yeah, but you put this together with the preemptive challenges in voir dire and serious leaders in the African-American community have a problem.
I'll talk to him.
Nah.
Leo.
No, it's over, Sam. I'm going to...
No.
I'm going to cancel....
No!
The President's stop and shut down the money.
You can't cut and run, Leo. JOSH (VO) We don't have any choice, Sam.
Of course we have a choice.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh is pacing around his apartment wearing a sweaty T-shirt.

Dialogues.Line: We got a chance at the House. We've only got 3 weeks left. Leo's got to put the President and the money where the President and money can win.
Tom Jordan is running against the man...
Well, you don't have to tell me.
You're going to hand it to him
Which will matter less if we get back the house.
Jordan is down by 7 and he's not going to come back from this.
Not only that, we stand by him, this is a national thing. It could drag down black turn out in districts where we're competitive.
I told him....
Yeah.
I told him we would stand by him. I told him he would have our full support. I was the one who asked him to run. I was asked to ask him.
I know.
We walk away now, that's it. He's a racist! The White House just said so!

We can't afford all the things we want, Sam. It's over. Leo puts on his glasses and the conversation is over. Sam leaves and slams the door on his way out. JOSH (VO) Hey, Leo. You know, there's a... something called the Super string Theory. Which at its most basic level says that the universe consists of these tiny loops of string that vibrate at different frequencies. Leo finds this information a bit inane.
How did that bullet not kill you?
Just lucky, I guess.
Yeah. He reaches over and pushes a button to hang up on Josh.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Toby is working at his desk. C.J. knocks and enters.

Dialogues.Line: Toby.
(without looking up) Yeah.
Any chance I can see an advanced copy of the President's remark for the Asia Pacific?
Um... what?
Asia Pacific.
I have a draft here. I'm going to rewrite it.
I thought I was going to have it by the end of the day.
The day's not over yet.

You know, Toby. These pieces everyone wants to do on the psychological aftermath of the shooting for the White House staff, they had me thinking. Do you think there might be a psychological aftermath and we're not paying attention to it?
C.J., I really don't have time to have this conversation.
I'm saying, I think you should have this conversation with somebody.
You think my problem is psychological?
I think you're Director of Communications and you've been ignoring operational responsibilities...
That's crap.
...So you can behave like the Director of the FBI.
Well, I'm waiting for the Director of FBI to behave that way.
Toby.
I'm waiting for the Justice department to behave that way. I'm waiting for Congress to behave that way. Charlie walks up.
I'm waiting for the White House to behave that way!
You want to lock up everybody with a white sheet?
Yes, I do. Yes, I do. Who has a problem with that? Bring 'em to me, right now. YES I DO! Charlie, who has been standing quietly, finally knocks lightly on Toby's door. C.J. turns around.
He's ready for me?
In the Residence.
Thank you. Charlie leaves. C.J. turns to Toby.
I'll be here for a while, so... whenever you can get me Asia Pacific.
Give me an hour. C.J. leaves. Toby sits and taps his pen on his desk, but we can see something is definitely bothering him.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is sitting reading some papers. Knock on the door.

Dialogues.Line: Come in.
[enters and closes the door] Good evening, Mr. President.
Hi, C.J.
Charlie said you wanted to see me.
Yeah. Why has there been no press mentioned that the fact that Elliot Roush was an opponent of mine in New Hampshire?
Elliot Roush is the man....?
He's running for a seat on the school board up in New Hampshire.
Yes, sir. I'm sure it's gotten some local coverage. I can have the news office run....
Why isn't it more than local?
It's a school board seat.
It's a human interest story.
Not a very interesting one.
I'm saying, if anyone in the Press Room wanted to do this story that I would comment on the record. C.J. takes a seat across from Bartlet.
Sir, the President can't publicly take sides in a local school board election.
Why can't he?

Because it's not done, and it's not fair. It's personal and it's irresponsible. It will galvanize the Republicans and the Democrats in Congress will think you've abandoned them, that you don't care about winning back the House.
I don't care about winning back the House.
Mr. President...
I don't care about winning back the House!
Well, I don't believe that's true so let's just keep that between you and me.

C.J., I've known men of faith in my life. Towering men. Men of wisdom and compassion. Men of all faiths, of healing and peace. Pro choices, pro-life, Republican, Democrat, men and women of God. Elliot Roush... (long beat) ...is polling at 53%. He's polling at 53%. He's the front runner.
Then that's the way it is. In a democracy, oftentimes, the other people win.
Yeah. It was just a thought, but I mean, obviously, you're right.
Yes, sir.
Thanks.
Thank you, Mr. President. C.J. gets up and leaves. Bartlet goes back to reading his papers.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - STORMY NIGHT
CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: Ginger!
They're still too close to call.
All twelve?
Yes.
Hey, give me somebody in the Midwest, would ya? (speaking to a room full of people) I want to see everyone on telephones. Sam looks around and realizes everyone is on the phones.
Okay, good...just like that. He enters his office where his friend, Tom and Sarah Jordan, are waiting. Sam is startled by their presence.
God...Tom, Sarah... I'm sorry. I forgot, I was... I'm sorry, I'm late. I'm glad you could make it.
It was no problem coming, Sam. Turns out there was really no reason for us to stay in our district on Election day.
Yeah, you've seen the exits. You're going to lose, Tom.
No, Kidding.
Probably 58-42.
Yeah.
42% is a very respectable number.
The district's 49% Democrat, Sam.
Well, we'll get them next time.
Shut up.
Sarah.
There's not going to be a next time! So, shut up! (beat) Not even a word from the White House. Not even a word.
That's how we do it.
Sam, any time we have the opportunity in the future to screw you. Count on getting screwed.
Good luck with the baby. Lightning flashes outside Sam's office as Tom and Sarah leave.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RECEPTION AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: We get a look at the reception for the Radio Talk Show Hosts. The camera pans down to two radio guys talking to C.J., who is looking confused, if not bored out of her mind.

Dialogues.Line: No, no, that was K-talk on Minneapolis. You're thinking Slam 100, sir, in the Great Lakes region. "The number one station with the number one sound."
But, then it was classic rock.
Or at least what our program director thought was classic rock. Fleetwood Mac, and what not.
Then they switched over to news and information back in '82?
We started with "Drive Time", then went to the 4 hour format.
Say, is Howard showing up today?
(waking up a bit) Stern.
I heard he was going to show up if Imus was coming and Imus wasn't showing up if Howard was coming.
By the way, I was "Dave in the Morning" before he was "Imus in the Morning." But that's... uh... water under the bridge.
Isn't Don Imus in this 70's?
I believe so, yes.
[chuckles] How are you "Dave in the Morning" before he was "Imus in the Morning?"
(taking it seriously) It was a very painful. I don't like to talk about it.
Okay. Fellas, I'm sorry, but it's Election Day and I need to check in with the exit polls...
Sure.
...and what not. Good meeting you both.
Good talking to you, C.J. C.J. turns away as a woman in a green business suit walks in. Photographers taking pictures and flashbulbs going off all over the place. C.J. walks up to Carol.
Who's that?
Jenna Jacobs.
That's Jenna Jacobs?
Yeah. She changed her hair.
[starts fluffing her hair] What's the latest?
12 races too close to call. Thompson, Marinovich....
I'm gonna go check. C.J. leaves the reception but gets one last look at JENNA JACOBS.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet is sitting in his chair going over some papers. Toby enters after knocking.

Dialogues.Line: Good evening, Mr. President.

Toby, I'm drinking the most fantastic thing I've ever tasted in my life: chocolate syrup, cold milk, and seltzer. I know it sounds terrible, but trust me, I don't know where this has been all my life.
It's called an egg cream, Mr. President. We invented it in Brooklyn.
In Brooklyn.
Yes, sir.
Not New England?
There are some good things in this world not from New England, sir.
Toby, don't ever let me hear you say that again.
Yes, sir.
What's on your mind?
Mr. President, I was thinking... I was thinking it might...
You want to take a leave of absence.
I was thinking I might need some time off, yes sir.
That's no problem, Toby.
Okay.
Not a problem at all.
Thank you, sir. [turns to leave]
15 minutes. Toby turns back around to face Bartlet.
It's time to get up off the mat, Toby.
Sir, what's to wrong with having the Attorney General designate potentially...
Toby.

...dangerous organizations that promote violent acts? I... I... understand it's problematic. Ah... uh... there'd be no judicial review, or legislative oversight, or even for that matter legal finding of fact, but... (big sigh) Okay... fine... fine... (choked up with emotion) Why does it feel like this? I've seen shootings before.

[rises from his chair] It wasn't a shooting, Toby. It was a lynching. They tried to lynch Charlie right in front of our eyes, can you believe that? Bartlet puts on his glasses and roots around for a file and hands it to Toby.
What's this?

Keyhole satellite photographs. It's the headquarters for West Virginia White Pride headquarters. It's a diner outside Blacksberg. Every night for the past 12 weeks, I've picked up the phone and called the Attorney General, fully prepared to say two wordstake 'em. And then I hang up the phone because I know it'll be better tomorrow and better the day after that. We saw a lynching, Toby. That's why it feels like this.
I'm not sure I'm going to come out of the other side of this.
I'm not sure I can either. But until we are sure, I think we should keep coming into work every day. [sits back down]
How's it going with your school board guy?
Yeah, he's gonna win.
When you ran against him, how'd you beat him?
I don't remember. I've been thinking about it for weeks, but I honestly don't remember. Knock at the door and Sam enters.
Excuse me, Mr. President. Good evening.
Hey, Sam.
I wasn't sure whether you'd be stopping by the Talk Radio reception. I scratched out a few remarks for you.
Let me look at them while we walk. Toby, go with us, to this radio thing.
Oh God, really sir?
There'll be crab puffs. New England crab puffs, by the way, made in New England.
Actually, it's Alaskan crab.
Sam.
There's Alaskan crab in this White House?
He wouldn't have known the difference.
Have you tried them?
I... yes, reluctantly. I think it was clear the way I ate the crab puffs that it was a gesture of protest.
Were they good?
Extraordinarily good and going very fast.
Let's get there. Thunder rumbles outside.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. RECEPTION AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: A waiter walks by with a platter of crab puffs. Photographers taking pictures of various guests. The camera pans up to C.J. talking with another radio personality.

Dialogues.Line: I call myself Gary with a "G".
How else would you spell "Gary"?
No other way. I'm saying, that's what I call myself. Therefore, "Gary with a "G", talking to you on KADR AM."
Like Liza with a "Z".
Exactly. Hokey? Maybe so, but I have 900,000 listeners in the Rocky Mountain region. A Secret Service Agent catches C.J.'s eye.
Would you excuse me? C.J. leaves Gary with a "G" and makes her way into the center of the room to introduce the President.
Excuse me, ladies and gentlemen. Ladies and gentlemen. The President of the United States. Everyone stands and claps. The flashbulbs go off as Bartlet enters the reception.

Thank you. Thank you, very much. Thanks a lot. I wish I could spend more than a few minutes with you but the polls don't close in the east for another hour and there are plenty of election results left to falsify. Everyone chuckles.

You know with so many people participating in the political and social debate through call in shows, it's a good idea to be reminded... Bartlet loses his train of thought when something attracts his attention. The camera pans over to Jenna Jacobs, sitting on her chair.
...it's a good idea to be reminded of the awesome impact... the awesome impact... He finally gives up and addresses her.
I'm sorry, um... you're Dr. Jenna Jacobs, right?
Yes, sir.
It's good to have you here.
Thank you.
The awesome impact of the airwaves and how that translates into the furthering of our national discussions but obviously also how it can... how it can... He sighs, and addresses Jenna Jacobs again.
Forgive me, Dr. Jacobs. Are you an M.D.?
Ph.D.
A Ph.D.?
Yes, sir.
In Psychology?
No sir.
Theology?
No.
Social work?
I have a Ph.D. in English Literature.

I'm asking, 'cause on your show, people call in for advice and you go by the name of Dr. Jacobs on your show. And I didn't know if maybe your listeners were confused by that, and assumed you had advanced training in Psychology, Theology, or health care.
I don't believe they are confused, no sir.
Good. I like your show. I like how you call homosexuality an abomination.
I don't say homosexuality is an abomination, Mr. President. The Bible does.
Yes, it does. Leviticus.

Chapter and verse. I wanted to ask you a couple of questions while I had you here. I'm interested in selling my youngest daughter into slavery as sanctioned in Exodus 21:7. (small chuckles from the guests) She's a Georgetown sophomore, speaks fluent Italian, and always clears the table when it was her turn. What would a good price for her be? While thinking about that, can I ask another? My Chief of Staff, LeoO McGarry, insists on working on the Sabbath, Exodus 35:2, clearly says he should be put to death. Am I morally obligated to kill him myself or is it okay to call the police? Here's one that's really important, 'cause we've got a lot of sports fans in this town. Touching the skin of a dead pig makes us unclean, Leviticus 11:7. If they promise to wear gloves, can the Washington Redskins still play football? Can Notre Dame? Can West Point? Does the whole town really have to be together to stone my brother, John, for planting different crops side by side? Can I burn my mother in a small family gathering for wearing garments made from two different threads? Jenna Jacobs fidgets uncomfortably.

Think about those questions, would you? One last thing, while you may be mistaking this for your monthly meeting of the Ignorant Tightass Club, in this building, when the President stands, nobody sits. Jenna Jacobs squirms in her seat but doesn't rise. Bartlet glares meaningfully at her. She finally rises out of her seat.
Toby.
Yes, Mr. President.
That's how I beat him. Bartlet leaves the reception. Toby and Jenna Jacobs exchange glances before Toby leaves. Sam approaches her, who is holding a plate of hors d'oeuvre.
I'm just... I'm gonna take that crab puff. Sam snatches up a crab puff off of her plate and leaves. She smiles awkwardly around.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTER OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Camera shot of a TV monitor and pans up to Charlie walking toward his desk. JEFFREY (OS) You want one of my animal crackers? Jeffrey is sitting in Mrs. Landingham's chair.

Dialogues.Line: I have elephants and I have lions.
[enters] You bugging the man?
No, we're okay. Is there a software problem again?
I think I got it. Just want to run a few programs and then I'll be out of here. (sits down) Pretty busy day around here, huh?
Yeah. My name is Charlie Young, by the way.
You don't think I don't know who you are? Man who almost got the President killed?
Yeah. That's going to look good on my resume.
I'll just be a minute. Lightning flashes outside.
My mother used to work nights, too.
I'm sorry?
My mother used to work nights, too.
Was she a nurse?
A police officer.
Is she gone?
She was shot and killed in the line a year ago, June. Ironically, she wasn't supposed to be on the shift. She switched shifts that day 'cause I asked her to. Long pause as they look at each other.
Hey, Charlie... um... you know what I think she'd say if she was here, right now?
What?
Same thing my father would say, "if they're shooting at you, you know you're doing something right."
Yeah. (beat) Yeah. (more lightening flashes and rumbles) ...yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE PORTICO - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Zoey is sitting in a chair on a balcony, reading a book. Charlie approaches her.

Dialogues.Line: Excuse me, aren't you Zoey Bartlet? Zoey gives a small smile and gets up to kiss Charlie
It's too much to happen to someone your age. Your father and your mother and then this... I don't know, Charlie. I mean... what do you do?
I was going to go vote.
I could come.
Yeah. Leo walks by.
Hi.
Hi, Leo.
Charlie, I'm looking for the President.
Is there anything wrong?
No, no... I... um.... I think he may have done a couple of numbers at the Talk Radio reception.
Okay. Zoey and I are going out. I'll be on my pager.
You're going out?
Yeah.
Charlie, you're taking extra protection, right? Charlie is a bit taken aback by that suggestion.
Hey, Leo....
Secret Service protection, Charlie. But thanks for loading me up with that image.
Yeah, we'll have extra protection.
Okay. Something about a dead pig's skin. I need to find him. Leo walks away as Charlie and Zoey looks confusingly at each other.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. JOSH'S APARTMENT STOOP - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: In a tree lined sidewalk, C.J., Josh and Donna are sitting on a stoop of one of the townhouses lining the sidewalk. Sam is nearby in a car talking on his cell phone.

Dialogues.Line: (into phone) Okay. Toby comes out of Josh's apartment and hands C.J. a bottle of beer.
Everybody should have to stay inside for three months so that they truly appreciate the outdoors. I appreciate the outdoors, now. I'm an outdoorsman.
Josh?
Yeah.
I said I'd let you outside if you'd stop talking about being an outdoorsman and if you stopped talking about Theoretical Physics.

(to C.J.) Aha! You'd thought I'd forget about it, didn't you? Banner headline, 5 days ago. Model for the Unified Theory solved. Banner headline in the New York Times. You said it wasn't going to be news.
Hey! You're wearing my pajamas.
Yes, I am.
Take your coat off, let's see. Josh stands up and shrugs off his coat to reveal oversized light blue pajamas that are three sizes too big.
Those are too big.
Yes, they are. All this time I've been working with you, did you also think I was playing power forward for the Cleveland Cavaliers?
I think they look good on you. (grabs Toby's arms)
I think you're all freaks. Sam gets off the phone and out of the car and approaches the stoop.
What do you have?
You're not going to believe it.
How'd they go?
Twelve races, in none of them did the incumbent win. In none of them, did the party that previously held the seat win. You know how it went? Seven to five.
You're kidding.
Seven republicans and five democrats?
Yeah.
The house stayed the same? Everyone looks at each other.
After four months and 400 million dollars, everything stayed the same.
Yup.

Tell me democracy doesn't have a sense of humor. We sit here, we drink this beer out here on the stoop, in violation about 47 city ordinances. I don't know, Toby, it's election night. What do you say about a government that goes out of its way to protect even citizens that try to destroy it?
God bless America.
(beat) God bless America.
God bless America.
God bless America.
God bless America. They all clink their bottles before the camera pulls away from the stoop.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
